column1: In Astro, files placed in {{c1::src/pages/::directory path}} automatically become routes in your application.
column2: Similar to Next.js Pages Router where files in pages/ become routes. Unlike Next.js App Router which uses app/ directory. The file name directly maps to the URL path.

column1: To create dynamic route parameters in Astro, use {{c1::[param]::bracket syntax}} syntax in the filename.
column2: For example, src/pages/posts/[id].astro creates a dynamic route that matches /posts/1, /posts/2, etc. Identical to Next.js Pages Router dynamic routes. The parameter name inside brackets becomes accessible via Astro.params.

column1: In an Astro page component, you access dynamic route parameters through {{c1::Astro.params::object property}}.
column2: Example: const { id } = Astro.params; in [id].astro. Similar to Next.js Pages Router where you destructure from context.params in getServerSideProps or getStaticProps.

column1: To match URL paths of any depth in Astro, use {{c1::[...path]::rest parameter syntax}} syntax in the filename.
column2: Example: src/pages/[...slug].astro matches /products, /products/astro, /products/astro/handbook, etc. Similar to Next.js catch-all routes [...slug]. Access via Astro.params.slug which contains the full path.

column1: The {{c1::getStaticPaths()::function name}} function in Astro is used to generate routes at build time for dynamic pages.
column2: Must be exported from .astro page files with dynamic parameters. Returns an array of objects with params and optional props. Similar to Next.js getStaticPaths but combined data fetching happens in same function or uses props.

column1: In Astro's getStaticPaths(), the {{c1::params::property name}} property defines the URL parameter values for each generated route.
column2: Example: return [{ params: { id: '1' } }, { params: { id: '2' } }]; generates /posts/1 and /posts/2. Each params object must match the dynamic segments in the filename.

column1: In Astro's getStaticPaths(), the optional {{c1::props::property name}} property passes data to the page component via Astro.props.
column2: Unlike params which must be strings and appear in the URL, props can be any serializable data. Example: return [{ params: { id: '1' }, props: { post: postData } }];. Similar to Next.js where you'd combine getStaticPaths and getStaticProps but here it's done in one function.

column1: To allow a rest parameter route to match the top-level page in Astro, set the rest parameter to {{c1::undefined::special value}}.
column2: Example: { params: { path: undefined } } in getStaticPaths() makes [...path].astro match the root / route in addition to nested paths. This is useful for catch-all routes that need to handle the base path.

column1: Astro performs redirects using the {{c1::Astro.redirect()::method call}} method for client-side navigation.
column2: Call this in the frontmatter code block: return Astro.redirect('/new-page');. Executes at build time for static sites or request time with SSR adapter. Can also configure redirects in astro.config.mjs for static redirects.

column1: In Astro route matching, {{c1::static routes::route type}} have higher priority than dynamic routes.
column2: For example, /posts/featured.astro will match before /posts/[id].astro when accessing /posts/featured. This prevents dynamic routes from shadowing specific static pages. Same priority system as Next.js routing.
